35 Chapter 1: Structural Dynamics Taylor Test with Euler Main Index Taylor Test with Euler For most structural problems, the Lagrange approach is the preferred solution. But if deformations become large, the Euler approach can become more accurate. As deformations are increased, the Lagrangian elements are severely distorted affecting the accuracy of the solution. In the Euler approach, severe distortion is irrelevant and does not exist. Eulerian elements are stationary and have a fixed volume; only the material inside the elements can move and is transported over the faces of the stationary Euler elements. In addition, the Euler approach does not need any contact definition when an impactor hits a plate. This example shows how the model from is handled by the multi-material Euler solver with strength. It also illustrates the use of PARAM, AXIALSYM. Problem Description The problem is the same as Taylor Test (a rod impacted against a rigid wall example. A bar impacts a rigid wall. This example will compare the results of a Lagrangian approach using the Johnson-Cook material model as shown in Example Taylor Test (a rod impacted against a rigid wall and an Euler simulation. SOL 700 Model Setup of the Euler Domain To construct the Euler mesh, a pie shape consisting of one layer of elements will be created as shown in Figure 1-18. Because the simulation will assume axi-symmetric behavior the following requirements are imposed on the Euler mesh domain: TAYLOR TEST WITH EULER For accuracy the angle of this pie should be small, say 5°. When creating a pie mesh with Patran, the grid points are written out in single precision, resulting in very small errors. The small errors are large enough to cause errors in the normals of the faces of Euler faces. A normal that is supposed to point in the circumferential direction gets a very small component in the axial and radial direction. For a problem involving strength, this leads to small dynamics in the circumferential direction. To keep the dynamics small and bounded, the stable time step has also to be based on the circumferential direction. The pie model has a small angle which results in a small mesh size and therefore a small time step. With DYPARAM, AXIALSYM, these grid points can be slightly corrected resulting in aligned normals. This technique results in a much larger time step. In addition, DYPARAM, AXIALSYM can be used to create a pie mesh directly from a rectangular block slab of elements. This approach has been followed in this example. First of all, a rectangular Euler mesh consisting of one layer has been defined in the input file. Secondly, DYPARAM,AXIALSYM transforms this mesh automatically into a pie shape mesh in the SOL 700 solver. Please refer to the reference guide for further information on this option.

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Taylor Test with Euler36 Main Index The Euler elements are defined by
MESH,1,BOX,,,,,,,+ +,0.0,0.0,0.0,26.0,0.2,3.82,,,+ +,128,1,44,,,,EULER,1 Figure 1-18 Pie Model To make this rectangular mesh into a pie-shaped mesh PARAM,AXIALSYM will be used: DYPARAM,AXIALSYM,RECT,X,ZX,2.5 The pie-shaped mesh will also be used in the initialization. The time step will only be based on the mesh- size in x and z-direction. The mesh size in the y-direction would require a much smaller time step. Since there is no dynamics in the y direction, the mesh size in y-direction can be left out. This is also defined by DYPARAM,AXIALSYM. Setup of Material and Initialization Data The multi-material Euler with strength solver will be used: First model: PEULER1,1,, STRENGTH,4 PEULER1,1,, MMSTREN,4 The material is defined by MATDEUL 18.96e-09 1 1 1 1 PMINC,1,-1.e+20 EOSPOL,1,143000

37 Chapter 1: Structural Dynamics Taylor Test with Euler Main Index SHREL,1,47700 YLDJC ,1,175,380,0.32,0.06,0.55,1,4.52e+008,+

  •   ,1811,293

TAYLOR TEST WITH EULER The Euler elements are initialized using geometric regions: TICVAL,3,,XVEL,-197000,DENSITY,8.96e-9 $ $ ——- TICEUL BC init-euler —– TICEUL1 4 4
TICREG 1 4 SPHERE 1 1.
TICREG 2 4 BOX 2 1 3 2.
$ SPHERE,1,,0.0,0.0,0.0,100.0 $ BCBOX,2,,,,,,,,+ +,,, 0.0 ,-0.3 , 0.0 ,25.4,-0.3, 0.0 ,+ +,,,25.4 , 0.3 , 0.0 , 0.0, 0.3, 0.0 ,+ +,,, 0.0 ,-0.3 , 1.91,25.4,-0.3, 1.91,+ +,,,25.4 , 0.3 , 1.91, 0.0, 0.3, 1.91 Results Results at time 4.8 e-5 sec are shown in Figure 1-19 and Figure 1-20. Figure 1-19 FMAT of the metal Figure 1-20 Plastic strain, Range 0 to 1.08

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Taylor Test with Euler38 Main Index As in cxample “ Taylor Test (a rod impacted against a rigid wall) ”, the rod elongates slightly after 0.48e-5 sec as shown in Figure 1-21. The total length reached at the end is 19.9. This translates into a reduction of length of 0.78. These results compare well with the results presented in “ Taylor Test (a rod impacted against a rigid wall) ” example. If the compression is more severe or when damage is used it is preferred to add PARAM, EULSTRESS,MASS. With this PARAM, stresses are transported by using mass instead of volume. The mass approach can be more accurate, but for this simulation it is not needed. Running the same problem with the single material strength solver also gives reasonable results, although the material is not as smooth. This is explained by the fact that the transport algorithms of the multi-mat strength solver are currently more sophisticated. Figure 1-21 Elongation as Function of Time

Figure 1-22 FMAT at Time 4.8e-5 seconds with the Strength Solver

41 Chapter 1: Structural Dynamics Hourglassing in Hexahedron Elements Main Index Hourglassing in Hexahedron Elements Problem Description Hourglass modes in simulations with 1-point integration hexahedron and quadrilateral elements are always present. In the past, a lot of research in suppressing these modes have been done in SOL 700 and other explicit codes. Therefore, nowadays, the hourglass modes are often suppressed to a sufficient level by default. However, in certain occasions, the modes are still persevering and can easily trouble the solution. A rigorous solution for this is the use of fully integrated quadrilateral and/or hexahedron elements. These elements do not exhibit hourglassing modes, and therefore, do not need hourglass suppressing terms in the algorithm. To illustrate the above, a load is applied to a plate modeled with one layer of hexahedron elements. The model has a load (linearly) applied in the top mid center and is supported in the lower corners. It will be shown that the new fully integrated hexahedron element in SOL 700 does not suffer from hourglassing. Theoretically, this can be proven because no hourglassing modes exist in the solution, contrary to the 1- point integration hexahedron element, which has several hourglassing modes. The model will be run with four different settings, as summarized in Table 1-1 Table 1-1 Summary of Analyses Settings The model properties are given in Table 1-2 Table 1-2 Properties of ModelCase Element Integration Method Hourglass Control MethodHourglass Control Coefficient 1 1-point – constant stress Stiffness Based (FBS) 0.1 2 2x2x2 points – fully integrated – - 3 1-point – constant stress Stiffness Based (FBS) 0.01 4 1-point – constant stress Viscosity Based (DYNA) 0.1 Dimensions Material, Linear Elastic Loads and BC’s LxB = 5x5 G = 7500 F = 400, linear in time up to 0.1 [sec] Thickness = 1 K = 16250 (as a result:  = 0.3) Clamped at bottom corner nodes. r = 1.2e-3

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Hourglassing in Hexahedron Elements42 Main Index SOL 700 Model The hexahedron mesh is shown in Figure 1-23. The model has one element over the thickness, and 64 elements in total. The force is applied on two nodes in the top center and the bottom corner nodes are clamped using a SPC. The force is ramped up linearly in 0.1 seconds to minimize oscillations. The ENDTIME is 0.1 seconds. Figure 1-23 Model Case 1 This case is using default settings. Case 2 Starting with the model of Case 1, choosing the following options on the PSOLID entry activates the 2x2x2 fully integrated hexa element: IN = 2 ISOP = FULL
Case 3 Starting with the model of Case 1, choosing the following option on the HGSUPPR entry activates the lower hourglass coefficient: HGCSOL = 0.01 Case 4 Starting with the model of Case 1, the overall hourglass control method for solids is modified to the viscous method, by entering the parameter: PARAM, HGCSOL,0.01

43 Chapter 1: Structural Dynamics Hourglassing in Hexahedron Elements Main Index Results The results for the four cases are shown in Figure 1-24 through Figure 1-27 below. Figure 1-24 shows that applying point loads as done in this example introduce hourglass modes when using 1point integration. Figure 1-25 shows that the hourglass modes do not occur when using the 2x2x2 integration method. Figure 1-26 shows that by lowering the hourglass control coefficient more severe hourglass modes occur. Figure 1-27 shows that the viscous hourglass mode suppression method is not working well in this example. This is understandable, because in general a viscous hourglass mode suppression method is only suited for problems with high velocities. Note that in all the figures, the displacements are all scaled up in order to show the hourglassing modes more clearly. Figure 1-24 Case 1: 1-Point Integration Hexa, Hourglassing to a Small Extent in the Bottom and Top Rows Notes: Displacements are scaled up.

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Hourglassing in Hexahedron Elements44 Main Index Figure 1-25 Case 2: 2x2x2 Fully Integrated Hexa, No Hourglassing Figure 1-26 Case 3: 1-Point Integration Hexa with Lower Stiffness Damping Coefficient (0.01) Notes: Displacements are scaled up. Notes: Displacements are scaled up.

45 Chapter 1: Structural Dynamics Hourglassing in Hexahedron Elements Main Index Figure 1-27 Case 4: 1-Point Integration Hexa with Viscous Hourglassing Suppression, Hourglassing very Clearly Present References (continued) 7.Dytran reference manual, chapter 5, Bulk data description of Hourglass suppression modes HGSUPPR Input Files Abbreviated SOL 700 Input File $ $ SOL 700 CEND ENDTIME=0.1 ENDSTEP=9999999 TITLE= Jobname is: Comparison-iso Notes: Displacements are scaled up. File Description Case 1 : 2x2x2.dat SOL 700 input files Case 2 : default.dat Case 3 : lowhgcoef.dat Case 4 : hgdyna.dat

item.title: User's Manual P4
item.description:
Main Index Chapter 2: Structural Contact Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear 2 Structural Contact Overview 50 Three-plate Contact 50 Tapered Beam Striking a Rigid Wall 56 Impact Loading 63 Pipe Whip 70

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Overview50 Main Index Overview In this chapter, a number of example problems are presented that show the capabilities of SOL 700 to model structural interaction. Through these examples, the user can learn how to model the interaction between structural parts using the different types of contact available in SOL 700. Three-plate Contact Problem Description Plates 1 and 3 are moving towards a third, resting Plate 2, which is located between them. The initial situation is given in Figure 2-1 below: Figure 2-1 Initial Situation The required data is shown below. Size of all three plates:

Material of the plates (steel): width in y-direction a = 2 m width in z-direction b = 2 m thickness t = 0.005 m density  = 7800 kg/m3 Young’s modulus E = 2.1 x 1011 N/mm2 Poisson’s ratio  = 0.3

51 Chapter 2: Structural Contact Three-plate Contact Main Index Initial conditions:

The purpose of this example is to investigate the treatment of contact between structures in SOL 700. Theoretical Result The conservation of momentum and energy will only be achieved if the plates are reflected with a velocity equal to the initial velocity but with reversed direction. For symmetry reasons, the central plate stays at rest. As shell elements (which are infinitely stiff in their normal direction) are used, the duration of the contact is theoretically approaching zero. SOL 700 Model The plates are modeled by 4 x 4 shell elements. The initial grid point velocities are prescribed using TIC
entries. The BCBODY entry refers to BSURF entries, which define the surfaces by sets of element faces or by property IDs of shell elements. In this example, a BSURF is defined for each shell element. The BSURF s of the plates 1, 2, and 3 are grouped in the IDs 1, 2, and 3, respectively. Three different ways to model the contact are compared. The following table shows how the surfaces and contacts are defined in three cases: Time histories for the position and velocities of grid points on each plate are requested for output. In addition, two Contact variables are requested for output. One is the magnitude of Contact force in the x-direction and the other is the smallest distance between secondary contact node and primary contact face. Results When a contact between two surfaces is defined, the code applies a constraint force pushing the corresponding parts away from each other, as soon as penetration occurs. In the case of the primary-secondary contact, the grid points of the secondary contact s urface are checked for penetration of the faces of the distance d = 0.005 m velocity v0 = 15 m/sec Primary Secondary Single Surface CASE 1 Contact 1 Contact 22 31 2 CASE 2 Contact 1 Contact 22 1 2,3 CASE 3 Contact 1 Contact 3 Contact 22 11 2 2,3

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Three-plate Contact52 Main Index primary contact s urface and the force is related to the depth of that penetration. The grid points of the primary contact s urface are not checked against the secondary contact s urface. In the case of the single surface contact, the algorithm checks all grid points for the penetration of any face of the surface. As the stiffness of the contact (which is a numerical and not a physical entity) is related to the number of penetrating grid points, the single surface contact is stiffer than the primary-secondary contact. In this example, it should behave exactly as two primary-secondary contacts with interchanged surfaces. The time histories of the central plate grid points velocities in x-direction agree with the expectations. The plots of Case 1 ( Figure 2-2) and Case 3 ( Figure 2-3) show that the energy and momentum are conserved and that symmetry is achieved. The acceleration of the plates during the contact has a finite value according to the finite numerical stiffness of the contact. Comparison of the plots show the stiffer behavior of the single surface contact. As a result of this, in Case 2 (Figure 2-4), there is a delayed exchange of momentum in the primary-secondary contact c ausing a part of the momentum to be transferred to the Plate 2.

Figure 2-2 Two Primary-Secondary C ontacts Result in a Symmetric Behavior

53 Chapter 2: Structural Contact Three-plate Contact Main Index Figure 2-3 A Single-surface Contact behaves as Stiff as Two Primary-Secondary Contact Interchanged Surfaces Figure 2-4 The Combination of a Single Surface Contact with a Single Primary-Secondary Contact produces an Unsymmetric Result

GRID 2 -.005 -.5 -1.
GRID 3 -.005 0.0 -1. GRID
4 -.005 .5 -1.
. . . GRID 72 .005 -.5 1. GRID 73 .005 -4.44-161. GRID 74 .005 .5 1. GRID 75 .005 1. 1. $Files Description pl3contact1.dat pl3contact2.dat pl3contact3.datSOL 700 input file for the three cases

TIC 1 2 1 15. TIC 1 3 1 15. TIC 1 4 1 15. . . TIC 1 51 1 -15. TIC 1 52 1 -15. TIC 1 53 1 -15. TIC 1 54 1 -15. $ $ $ $ THIS SECTION CONTAINS THE DEFINED FEFACES OF ELEMENTS $ $ $! Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Tapered Beam Striking a Rigid Wall56 Main Index Tapered Beam Striking a Rigid Wall Problem Description In the case of an impact between a moving object (given an initial velocity v0) and a rigid stationary wall, it is common for the user to request forces, stresses, and deformations resulting from this impact. In some cases, it might be easier to consider an equivalent problem where the object has no initial velocity and where the rigid wall is given a constant velocity v(t) = –v0. The resulting forces, stresses, and deformations are exactly equal for both cases since the first problem is identical to the second problem if the frame of reference is moving with the same velocity v0. To verify that SOL 700 is consistent with this theoretical result, two alternative analyses are used to model the impact of a tapered beam (made of steel with a length of 1 m and a weight of 40.71 kg) with a rigid plate. In the first case, the beam is given an initial velocity of 100m/sec while the plate is fixed. In the second case, the plate is given a constant velocity of –100 m/sec while the beam has no initial velocity but is free to move. The properties of the beam are as follows: Beam Desired Results The two alternative analyses should yield the same results with respect to forces, stresses, and deformations. Furthermore, the resulting velocities and momentum of the tapered beam for both cases should differ by exactly 100 m/sec and 100 kg m/sec for every time step, respectively. SOL 700 Modeling The plate is modeled using 5 x 5 (25) Belytschko-Tsay shell elements (CQUAD4) covered by BCBODY/BSURF . Using the PSHELL using MATRIG entries, the plate is defined as a rigid body as well as a Lagrangian contact surface. Using the TLOAD1 entry (TYPE = 12) and the FORCE entry, the plate is given a constant velocity of 0 m/sec and 100 m/sec in the first and second case, respectively. The tapered beam is built from 4 x 20 (80) nonuniform CHEXA elements that get smaller towards the one end. The PSOLID entry together with the MATDEUL , EOSPOL , SHREL , YLDVM , and PMINC entries define a steel material property for the beam. The front part of the beam, which is in contact with the plate, material steel density  = 7830 kg/m3 mass m = 40.71 kg bulk modulus K = 1.64 x 1013 N/m2 shear modulus G = 8.18 x 1012 N/m2 yield stress  = 1.4 x 1011 N/m2 spall pressure ps = –3.8 x 109 N/m2

57 Chapter 2: Structural Contact Tapered Beam Striking a Rigid Wall Main Index is covered by BCBODY/BSURF to define a Lagrangian contact surface. In the first case, all the grid points of the beam are given an initial velocity of 100 m/sec by using the TIC entry. Finally, the BCTABL1 with BCONECT entry defines the contact between the beam ( secondary contact surface) and the plate ( primary contact surface) . Results As shown in Figure 2-5 through Figure 2-10, the results are identical for both cases, as expected. Figure 2-5 Moving Beam - Effective Stress Contour of the Deformed Beam after 1200 Cycles

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Tapered Beam Striking a Rigid Wall58 Main Index Figure 2-6 Moving Plate – Effective Stress Contour of the Deformed Beam after 1200 Cycles Figure 2-7 Z-Forces for a Grid Point on the Front of the Beam – The Curves are identical for both Cases

59 Chapter 2: Structural Contact Tapered Beam Striking a Rigid Wall Main Index Figure 2-8 Z-velocities for Grid Point on the Front of the Beam – The Upper Curve is derived from the Moving Beam Case Figure 2-9 Z-momentum averaged over all the Grid Points of the Beam – The Upper Curve is derived from the Moving Beam Case

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Tapered Beam Striking a Rigid Wall60 Main Index Figure 2-10 Average Kinetic Energy Conservation of all the Grid Points for both the models Input Files Abbreviated SOL 700 Input File SOL 700 CEND TITLE = Moving plate strikes fixed beam. $CHECK = NO ENDSTEP = 1200 DLOAD = 1 IC = 3 SPC = 1 BCONTACT = 1 $$ $$ Data for output control Set 1 $$ $S700 TYPE (BEAM) = ARCHIVE $S700 ELEMENTS (BEAM) = 8 $S700 SET 8 = 1t80 $S700 ELOUT (BEAM) = EFFSTS,PRESSURE,EFFPLS $S700 STEPS (BEAM) = 0,THRU,END,BY,50 $S700 SAVE (BEAM) = 10000File Description tapered_beam1.dat SOL 700 input files (case 1) tapered_beam2.dat SOL 700 input files (case 2)

63 Chapter 2: Structural Contact Impact Loading Main Index Impact Loading Overview A simple elastic bar is subjected to an impact load on one end and supported on the other end. The impact load on the elastic bar is applied by a rigid body with mass m = 0.00311 lbs2/in and an initial velocity v0= 240 in/s. The elastic bar has the following properties: The purpose of this model is to study the response of the simple elastic bar to impact loading and to check the results against theoretical data. Theoretical Results The contacted end of the elastic bar experiences an impulse, which causes an internal force locally in the bar. This pulse starts traveling down the length of the bar and the force in the bar at any point away from the impacted end remains zero until the distortional pulse reaches that point. The distortional pulse (stress wave) travels with at a fixed velocity equal to the speed of sound in solids, which is a function of material density and stiffness. The magnitude of the initial pulse is given by: The fixed velocity of the distortional pulse is given by: The time required by the pulse to traverse the entire length of the bar is given by: From the conservation of energy, the magnitude of peak load in the bar is: SOL 700 Model Due to one-dimensional problem, a simple mesh is set up (see Figure 2-11).Cross sectional area A = 0.2025 in2 Material density 0.000262 lb.s2/in4 Young’s modulus E = 10.5 x 106 psi Bar length L = 6.00 in. PpulseA0E2.549lb = = c E 2000322ins = = tL c— 0.03ms = = PmaxEAm L————x0 7967lb = =

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Impact Loading64 Main Index The rigid body is modeled as a single Lagrangian solid CHEXA element of dimension 0.5 in x 0.5 in x 0.5 in. The elastic bar is modeled as 1 x 40(40) equidistant Lagrangian solid CHEXA elements for the entire length of 6 inches and all the nodes at one end of the bar is constrained in all directions. All the nodes of the rigid body are given an initial velocity of 240 in/s. A cross-section is defined at the centre of the bar using SECTION option to monitor the axial force at the centre of the bar. Figure 2-11 Numerical Problem Layout showing CHEXA Lagrangian Solid Elements. Results The plot for the axial cross-sectional force at the centre of the bar is shown in Figure 2-12. It can be seen from the plot that the time taken for the stress wave to travel the entire length of the bar is t = 0.03ms. After the stress wave reaches the fixed ends of the bar, it gets reflected as a compressive wave traveling back towards the impactor. Because the initial pulse did not impart the entire impact energy to the bar, the impactor is still moving forward. Therefore, a secondary compressive pulse is initiated with a slightly lower magnitude than the initial pulse because the velocity of the impactor is slightly reduced. This secondary pulse adds directly to the reflected initial pulse. This process continues with the addition of ever diminishing pulse magnitudes

65 Chapter 2: Structural Contact Impact Loading Main Index until all the impact energy has been absorbed. The correlation between the theoretical values and the numerical values obtained from the SOL 700 result plots are very good. Figure 2-12 Plot for Axial Force at the Center of the Bar Figure 2-13 Plot for Effective Stress of the Bar @0.0007 secs

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Impact Loading66 Main Index Input Files Reference Comparing initial conditions at cycle 1 with 1-D result. 1.Jones, Rodney H., Hethcock, J. Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Pipe Whip70 Main Index Pipe Whip Problem Description A tubular pipe that rotates with an initial velocity of 200 radians/s around one end hits another tubular pipe that is clamped on both ends:

Figure 2-14 Initial Configuration of Pipe Whip Model The overall dimensions and material properties of both pipes are the same, and are shown below:

The center of rotation of the rotating pipe is equal to the center point of its one rear end. The impact point is at the middle of the stationary pipe and for the rotation pipe, it is at a distance of 0.9144 m from the rotation center. The initial rotational velocity is 200 radians/s.Radius R = 0.1778 m Length L = 1.524 m Thickness t = 0.01097 m Density  = 7827 kg/m3 Young’s modulus E = 2.07E11 Pa Poisson’s Ratio  = 0.3 Yield Stress y = 3.1E11 Pa * *A very high Yield Stress has been defined to mimic almost elastic behavior. This will result in a quick rebound of the rotating pipe, and is meant for demonstration purposes only.

71 Chapter 2: Structural Contact Pipe Whip Main Index The calculation is carried out from the time just before the impact until the time that the rotating pipe begins to reverse. The Problem Time is 3 msec. SOL 700 Model The pipes are modeled with quadrilateral shell elements, and a contact is defined between the rotating pipe and the stationary pipe. An additional self-contact is defined for the rotating pipe. A MAT1 with MATEP is used to define the material. In order to easily apply the rotational boundary condition, a plate closes off the pipe, and an SPC is applied to the center node. This plate is given a thickness 10 times higher than the thickness of the pipe itself. This mimics a rigid connection between all the nodes in the rotation plane. The entire analysis from modeling to postprocessing is carried out by using the Dytran Preference of Patran. Results From the Time History of the Kinetic Energy of Material_1, it can be seen that the rotating pipe has bounced back around 2.5 mseconds as shown in Figure 2-15 Figure 2-15 Kinetic Energy of Rotating and Stationary Pipe The deformation of the pipes at 3 msec is shown in the Figure 2-16

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Pipe Whip72 Main Index . Figure 2-16 Deformed Shape at 3 msec. Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Basic Blast Analysis76 Main Index Basic Blast Analysis This example demonstrates the effect of detonation on the environment. The details of this example are as in the table as follows: Example Title Basic Blast Analysis Description & features The effect of a detonation on the environment can be simulated by assuming that the detonated material can be idealized by a sphere of hot gas with a homogeneous density and specific internal energy. This approach is suited for problems in which the processes inside of the explosive material are not to be investigated. In this guide, the propagation of a blast wave will be simulated starting from the initial shock front radius R0 = 0.05 m at the time t = 0 sec until it reaches a radius of R = 10 R0. Both, the gas in the sphere and the surrounding environment behave as an ideal gas (Gas Constant = 1.4). Geometry Material properties Blast Products (r < R0) specific internal energy = 1.29 1010 Joule/kg density = 7.74 kg/m3 Environment (Air at Room Temperature, r > R0) specific internal energy = 1.938 105 Joule/kg density = 1.29 kg/m3 The index “1” denotes values at the shock front and the index “0” values in the ambient atmosphere.

77 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Basic Blast Analysis Main Index Introduction A theoretical solution is available for a spherical blast wave originating from a point source (Taylor’s similarity solution. Assuming 1 » 0, the evaluation of the Rankine-Hugoniot relations deliver in the case of a blast wave: (3-1) This relation has been considered in the given problem setup. Assuming a point source and internal energy E, the pressure at the shock front (r = R) should be (3-2) Inserting the initial conditions yields (3-3) and (3-4) Figure 3-1 Radial Pressure Distribution for Several Time Steps and Theoretical Maximum PressureAnalysis Characteristics T ransient explicit dynamic analysis ( SOL 700) Boundary conditions T wo regions (high and low pressure) are defined with transient initial values Element type 8-node hex elements for Euler FE results SIE & Pressure distribution plot 1 0—–1+ 1–———– =  0.155 E0r3–= E e114 3—R031.6641E7 J = = 1R 2.58E6 J R3–=

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Basic Blast Analysis78 Main Index The results of the simulation should converge to this solution as the radius of the shock front increases.The analysis should generate an x-y plot of the pressure distribution along the x-axis and compare it with the theoretical solution. Also, a contour plot should be produced to check the spherical shape of the expanding pressure front. Basic Blast Input Files Basic Blast SOL 700 Modeling The motion of the gas is radial. Therefore, only a part of the area of interest need to be analyzed. Here, a mesh of 20 x 20 x 20 hexahedral Eulerian elements has been used for investigating the volume (0 < x < 0.3 m, 0 < y < 0.5 m, 0 < z < 0.5 m). The center of the blast wave is located at the origin of the global coordinate system. A higher level has to be used to indicate the higher priority of the spherical condition. The value for the parameter INISTEP has to be below the minimal time step that follows from the Courant Criterion: (3-5) where l denotes the smallest element dimension, c0 the initial speed of sound, and S is a safety factor Dytran’s default value is 2/3). With and Equation (3-5) yields for the time step seconds. Therefore, the value 1.96E-7 sec is used for the INISTEP parameter. Basic Blast SOL 700 Results Figure 3-2 shows pressure profiles in the elements 1 to 20, which are located along the edge y = z = 0 m of the control volume. The theoretical value of the shock front pressure is also included in this plot.Though this mesh is very coarse, the analysis results is a fairly good approximation of the theoretical values. Note that at t = 0, element 2 is not completely inside of the sphere of high energy gas. Therefore, its pressure is below that of element 1 at t = 0 sec.File Description blast_new_sol700.dat SOL 700 input file tSl c0—– = l10R020 0.025 m = = c01–e1= t1.96E-7 =

79 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Basic Blast Analysis Main Index Figure 3-2 Pressure Contour Plot for Step 50 The contour plot of the pressure in Figure 3-2 shows an almost spherical shape of the shock front. Deviations are due to the fact that mass transport takes place along element faces only. Thus, the relief of pressure is hampered for the elements on the diagonal. Reference (Continued) 4. Baker, W. E., Explosions in Air, University of Texas Press, 1973, Austin and London. Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear JWL Blast Analysis82 Main Index JWL Blast Analysis This example demonstrates detonation of high explosives. The details about this example are in the table as follows: Example Title JWL Blast Analysis Description & features Detonation of High Explosives (HE) Hydrodynamic Theory of Steady-state Plane Detonation Steady-state Detonation Modeling with SOL 700 Geometry Material properties Specific chemical energy q0 = 4.95 106 Joule/kg Detonation velocity D = 7980 m/sec Density 0 = 1717 kg/m3 The explosive material data is shown below: JWL equation of state parameters A = 5.24229 10E11 B = 0.07678 10E11 R1 = 4.2 R2 = 1.1 = 0.34 Analysis Characteristics T ransient explicit dynamic analysis (SOL 700)

83 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics JWL Blast Analysis Main Index Introduction The purpose of this example is to model the detonation of the explosive and to check the pressure behind the detonation front (peak pressure) against the theoretical Chapman-Jouguet value. Theoretical Background Detonation of High Explosives (HE) Detonation is the mechanism by which the high explosive materials release their chemical energy The chemical reaction, causing the energy release, takes place in a narrow zone (reaction zone) which propagates at high speed through the explosive that transforms the solid explosive into hot compressed gasses. The reaction zone is then a form of discontinuous wave, like a shock wave, with physical behavior that is governed solely by the properties of the unreached and completely reacted material on either side of the wave. This means that a hydrodynamic approach of detonation can be used. Hydrodynamic Theory of Steady-state Plane Detonation The model of the plane, steady-state reaction zone propagating at constant speed D through the explosive is depicted in Figure 3-3. Figure 3-3 Plane Reaction Zone Propogating at Constant Speed The Rankine-Hugoniot relations, which express the conservation of mass, momentum, and energy in the material stream flowing through the reaction zone, are used to relate the hydrodynamic variable across the reaction zone.Boundary conditions T wo regions (high and low pressure) are defined with transient initial values Element type 8-node hex elements for Euler FE results Pressure distribution plot

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear JWL Blast Analysis84 Main Index Conservation of mass and momentum (3-6) Conservation of energy (3-7) Equation (3-6) describes a straight line (Rayleigh line) defining the locus of all possible final states ( p,V) attainable by a discontinuous transition from the initial state (p0, V0) consiste nt with conservation of mass and momentum. Equation (3-7) is purely thermodynamic from which, with a given equation of state p = p (V, e) for the detonation products, the energy term may be eliminated, resulting in the Hugoniot curve of the explosive. The Hugoniot curve defines a concave downward curve locus of all possible final states (p, V) attainable by a discontinuous transition from the initial state (p0, V0) consistent with conservation of energy. See Figure 3-4. Figure 3-4 Hugoniat Curve and Rayleigh Line The forms of the Rayleigh line and Hugoniot curve are such that their interaction permits the existence of any detonation speed D above a minimum value and each value of D is consistent with two possible final states for the detonation products. One further condition is therefore required. Chapman and Jouquet added the following condition to conservation of mass, momentum, and energy: The detonation speed D is such that the Rayleigh line is tangent to the Hugoniot curve of the explosive (or the detonation speed is the minimum velocity consistent with the Rankine-Hugoniot relations). this process is shown in Figure 3-5.pp0–D2 V02——-V0V– = ee0–1 2—pp0+V0V–q0+ =

85 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics JWL Blast Analysis Main Index Figure 3-5 Hugoniot Curve and Reyleigh Line For Detonation Process According to the above considerations if the ideal gas equation of state (with constant specific heat ratio ) is used to model the detonation products, the following formulas result: Pcj = 2(q00 (3-8) (3-9) These relations are applicable also when using the JWL equation of state (with variable specific heat ratio) if measuring cj at the Chapman-Jouguet state (Pcj, Vcj) behind the detonation front. Steady-state Detonation Modeling with SOL 700 SOL 700 use the programmed burn technique to model the detonation of high explosives (HE).The basic assumption of this technique is that the reaction zone propagates in all directions at a constant speed equal to the Chapman-Jouguet detonation velocity Dcj As the reaction zone reaches and proceeds into an element, the chemical energy is proportionally released into that element over its burn time . The arrival and burn times of each element are computed according to Figure 3-6 below: Figure 3-6 Arrival Times of Detonation Wave Vcj 1+———–V0=

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear JWL Blast Analysis86 Main Index The following input entries are required when modeling detonation: JWL Blast Input Files Preparing Input Due to symmetry, the reaction zone (detonation front) is a plane traveling along the length of the slab. Therefore, it is sufficient to model only a portion of the slab with all boundary faces closed to transport. A mesh of 200 elements along the 50 cm of slab length is used (element thickness of 0.25 cm). Figure 3-7 Geometrical Layout of Explosive and Detonation Point At the start time, all the elements are filled with explosive material. Therefore, they all reference a EOSJWL equation of state defined by a DMAT entry. The specific chemical energy q0 is assigned as the initial specific internal energy of the explosive by using the TICEL entry. The Chapman-Jouguet detonation velocity Dcj, the ignition point, and the ignition time are specified by the DETSPH entry. The ignition time is taken as the start time of the analysis and the ignition point is the center of the left face of the mesh. See Figure 3-7. The duration of the analysis is set to 60 sec necessary to burn the slab (50 cm) at a detonation speed of 7980 m/sec. Edits of pressure profiles are requested every 10 sec.EOSJWL Defines equation of state of detonation products. TICEL Is used to assign the specific chemical energy as initial specific internal energy of each element. DETSPH Defines the ignition point, ignition time and speed of a “spherical” detonation front. File Description jwl.dat SOL 700 input file

87 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics JWL Blast Analysis Main Index JWL Blast Results The solution of the detonation analysis is shown in Figure 3-8. The peak pressure of each profile corresponding to the pressure behind the detonation front is depicted in Figure 3-9 in terms of the Chapman-Jouguet pressure fraction. From the hydrodynamic theory of steady-state plane detonation for a -law gas, the CJ pressure is Pcj = 2(cjq00 (3-10) with cj = 2.706 for TNT , this leads to Pcj = 2.9 * 1010 Pa (3-11) The code needs about 60 elements to build up the detonation front at which time the pressure reaches approximately 0.85 of Pcj. Subsequently, the front propagates with only a small increase of pressure. These results are acceptable if the fact is taken into account that SOL 700 is a first-order code that smears the shock front over a number of elements (always conserving momentum and energy). The result of that will be a reduction in peak pressure Figure 3-8 Peak Pressure Profiles at Different Distances

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear JWL Blast Analysis88 Main Index Figure 3-9 Pressure Distribution Plot Abbreviated SOL 700 Input File The following is an example of abbreviated SOL 700 input file: SOL 700,NLTRAN STOP=1 $ $TITLE = HE DETONATION TEST $CHECK = NO SUBCASE 1 $ENDSTEP = 200 ENDTIME = 6e-05 IC = 1 $ $$ Data for Output Control Set 1 $$ $S700 TYPE(p) = ARCHIVE $S700 SAVE(p) = 99999 $S700 ELEMENTS(p) = 1 $S700 SET 1 = ALLEULHYDRO $S700 ELOUT(p) = PRESSURE $S700 TIMES(p) = 0tEndb3e-06 BEGIN BULK PARAM INISTEP 2e-07 PARAM MINSTEP 1e-08 $ $ $ THIS SECTION CONTAINS BULK DATA $ $ GRID 1 0.0 0.0 0.0
GRID 2 0.0 .01 0.0
GRID 3 0.0 0.0 .01

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Shock Tube Analysis90 Main Index Shock Tube Analysis This example demonstrates the fluid-structural interaction. The details of this example are available in the table as follows: Example Title Shock T ube Analysis Description & features Study of propagation of shock waves in hypervelocity events Closed form solution & one-dimensional plane shock Geometry Material properties Euler (Air) Gas constant = 1.4 Density = 0.125 kg/m3 Density = 1.0 kg/m3 Specific Internal Energy = 2.5 joule/kg-kelvin Specific Internal Energy = 2.0 joule/kg-kelvin Analysis Characteristics T ransient explicit dynamic analysis (SOL 700) Boundary conditions T wo regions (high and low pressure) are defined with transient initial values Element type 8-node hex elements for Euler FE results 1.SSPD along the length of tube 2.Material Velocity along the length of the tube 3.SIE & Pressure distribution plot

91 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Shock Tube Analysis Main Index Introduction The propagation of shock waves is an important consideration for many SOL 700 application areas. Shock tube gas dynamics constitute a relatively simple process and as such a closed form solution can be found by analytical means. For one-dimensional plane shock, two adjacent regions of gas are initialized at time = 0 and there is a single discontinuity at the boundary between them . Figure 3-10 One-Dimensional Plane Shock At time  0, the situation is much more complex. At point b, the expansion front of the compressed material has a velocity Ub, the sound speed of the compressed material. Point c is the contact front between the compressed and uncompressed materials and has a velocity Uc, and point s is the shock front with velocity Us. In the region between c and s, the material variables are constant ( , P , Uc) with a local sound speed. This time region is therefore useful for the study of hypervelocity events.

Figure 3-11 Density and Velocity Profiles in a Shock Tube

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Shock Tube Analysis92 Main Index Desired Results For this example, the ideal gas equation of state is used. The initial conditions are:

A time 0, the analytical technique produces the following results:

SOL 700 Input Files SOL 700 Modeling T wo models were analyzed with different mesh densities. In both models, hydrodynamic Euler elements are used, and the gas regions are initialized using a TICEUL entry. (See Chapter 2, Eulerian Elements of the Dytran User’s Guide. )High Pressure Low Pressure  = 1  = 0.125 u = 0 u = 0 e = 2.5 e = 2.0 P = 1 P = 0.1 P =3.03130 Pc=0.303130 R=0.265574 L=0.426319 eR=2.85354 eL=1.77760 Uc=0.927453 (peak flow velocity: at point c) File Description new_sol700_eul1_coarse.dat SOL 700 input file

93 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Shock Tube Analysis Main Index Coarse Model The shock tube is modeled using 2500 (5 x 5 x 100) CHEXA elements. The numerical mesh is given inFigure 3-12. Figure 3-12 Coarse Finite Element Mesh Fine Model The shock tube is modeled using 5000 (5 x 5 x 200) CHEXA elements. SOL 700 Results The sharpness of the steps in the graph as produced by a SOL 700 analysis is dependent on how fine a mesh is used. This effect can be seen by comparing the graphs produced from the two analyses. Coarse Model The results are plotted in Figure 3-13 and Figure 3-14 show that the variation of material variables along the length of the shock tube. A selective number of elements along the axis of the shock tube were selected for this purpose.

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Shock Tube Analysis94 Main Index Figure 3-13 Length along the Shock Tube plotted against Material Density Figure 3-14 Length along the Shock Tube plotted against Material Sound Speed and Material Velocity Fine Model The fine model shows the effect of a finer mesh on the resolution of the results graphs (see the graphs shown in Figure 3-15 and Figure 3-16).

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method98 Main Index EOSGAM 1 1.4
$ TICEUL 1 +

  •   ELEM    2       1       12      2.

SET1 1 1251 THRU 2500
SET1 2 1 THRU 1250
$ TICVAL 11 density .125 zvel 0.0 sie 2.
TICVAL 12 density 1. zvel 0.0 sie 2.5 ENDDATA Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method Problem Description In many blast applications, the explosive is spherically symmetric and small compared to the distance from ignition point to target. An efficient method is developed to reduce the computation time significantly by initializing the spherical blast wave by constructing a 1-D model first, and then as the wave progresses and expands, the pressure wave is mapped to a full 3-D model just before the blast wave reaches the structure. The pressure in the wave front should be adequately maintained during the mapping process by avoiding excessive coarse mesh. This limits the amount of mesh coarsening one can apply. To validate mapping, the 1- D mesh and the 3-D mesh will have comparable mesh-sizes. In addition, mapping on a coarser mesh is also considered. To model the blast, ideal gas is used. The initial radius of the sphere will be R0=0.1 m. Ideal gas model: Blast Products (r<R0) Environment (r>R0) The simulation will be run for 0.843 ms. Remapped results will be compared with results that do not use remapping.Specific internal energy =9.E+6 Joule/kg Density =10 kg/m3 Gamma =1.4 Specific internal energy =3.E+5 Joule/kg Density =1 kg/m3

99 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method Main Index Nastran SOL 700 Modeling The Spherical model The Euler region is defined and initialized as follows: MESH,1,BOX,,,,,,,+ +,0,-0.001,-0.001,0.5,0.002,0.002,,,+ +,15,1,1,,,,EULER,1 This defines one row of Euler elements. To make the mesh suitable for spherical symmetric analyses DYPARAM SPHERSYM is added DYPARAM,SPHERSYM,RECT,X,2.0 This transforms the rectangular 1-D mesh into a wedge-shaped mesh. In addition, only the radial mesh size will be taken into account in the time step computation. In the 1-D spherical modeling technique, the analysis has to be terminated as soon as the material starts leaving the 1-D mesh model. In this example, the last cycle (cycle 48, t=0.11 ms,) where the material is still inside the domain, is considered. To import the 1-D result into the 3-D simulation, go through the following steps: Read in the Euler archives in Patran and select a cycle in which the material has not left the domain yet. In Patran Click Results->Graph Set as target entries the centers of the Euler elements and select variables. After apply, a graph isshown Converting the graph to a text file ( .xyd file): a.Click XYPOT . b.Select Create->XYwindow and create a new window. c.Click POST> Curve . Select a curve and Apply . d.Click Modify->Curve . e.Select the Curve and Apply . f.Select Data from Keyboard . g.Check Write XY Data to file and apply. This writes out a text file. For the remap, text files have to be created for density, specific internal energy (SIE), and radial velocity. These are called rho.xyd , sie.xyd , and vel.xyd . The follow-up 3-D model: The Euler region is defined and initialized as follows: MESH,1,BOX,,,,,,,+ +,-1,-1,-1,2,2,2,,,+ +,60,60,60,,,,EULER,1 TICEUL1 19 1 TICREG 1 1 SPHERE 3 100 8 4.

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method100 Main Index TICREG 2 1 SPHERE 4 100 9 2.

$ TABFILE allows defining a table from a text file. The full 3-D model : To check the integrity of the remapped results, a full 3-D model will also be simulated and results will be compared to the previous method. The Euler region is defined and initialized as follows: MESH,1,BOX,,,,,,,+ +,-1,-1,-1,2,2,2,,,+ +,60,60,60,,,,EULER,1 The material initialization is identical to the spherical 1-D model.

101 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method Main Index The follow-up 3-D model coarse model: The Euler region is defined and initialized as follows: MESH,1,BOX,,,,,,,+ +,-1,-1,-1,2,2,2,,,+ +,30,30,30,,,,EULER,1 In this example, the following calculations have been performed. 1.Spherical Model 2.Follow-up 3-D Model 3.Full 3-D Model 4.Follow-up 3-D Coarse model Results Spherical Model The mesh and the results of the spherical symmetric model are shown in the following figures: Mesh Density at 100th Cycle SIE at Time = 0. 11ms Radial Velocity at Time = 0.11 ms

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method102 Main Index The remap data are shown in the following figures: Rho.xyd SIE.xyd V el.xyd

103 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method Main Index Follow-up 3-D Model The initial conditions of the follow-up 3-D model at cycle 1 closely resemble the spherical symmetric solution results at cycle 48 as shown in the following figures: 3D Mesh(60x60x60)Density at Cycle 1 SIE at Cycle 1 Velocity Magnitude at Cycle 1

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method104 Main Index The validation of the 1-D to 3-D remap is shown in the following figures.

105 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method Main Index The following figure shows the pressure at time = 0.733 ms (cycle 76). This time represents the total problem time of 0.843 ms (1D + 3D=0.773+0.11). Full 3-D Model The results of the full 3-D model at Time = 0.11 ms (cycle 48) is shown in the following figure. This time is equivalent to the time of cycle 1 of the 3-D remap run.

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method106 Main Index The use of an orthogonal mesh is clearly visible in the square shape. The following figure shows the pressure profile comparison with the 3-D remap run at cycle 1. The following figure shows the pressure distribution at time = 0.836 ms. This compares well with the 3 -D results using remap. The pressures in the wave front are very similar.

107 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method Main Index Follow-up 3-D Coarse Model 3-D Coarse Mesh (30 x 30 x30)

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling Blast Wave using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Method108 Main Index Comparing initial conditions at cycle 1 with 1-D result.

$ $ MESH,1,BOX,,,,,,,+ +,-1,-1,-1,2,2,2,,,+ +,30,30,30,,,,EULER,1 $ $ ENDDATA Modeling the JWL Explosion using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Problem Description The JWL model requires very fine mesh to reach the correct peak pressure. After sufficient expansion of the blast wave, fine elements are no longer useful and it would be very computationally efficient to replace the fine mesh by a coarse mesh. Furthermore, the initial stages of the explosion are spherical symmetric and allows the use of a 1-D model. As in the previous example, the spherical initialization is done by constructing a 1-D model and results are remapped on a first quadrant 3-D model. The air outside the explosive will also be modeled. The multi- material Eulerian solver is used.

117 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling the JWL Explosion using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Main Index The initial radius of the sphere will be R0=0.25 m. Blast Products (r<R0) JWL model, Environment (r>R0) The simulation will be run for 2.5 ms. Nastran SOL 700 Modeling Spherical Symmetric Model The Euler region is defined and initialized as follows: MESH,1,BOX,,,,,,,+ +,0,-0.001,-0.001,4,0.002,0.002,,,+ +,1600,1,1,,,,EULER,1 This defines one row of Euler elements. T o make the mesh suitable for spherical symmetric analyses PARAM SPHERSYM is added PARAM,SPHERSYM,RECT,X,1.0 This transforms the rectangular 1-D mesh into a wedge shaped mesh. Also, in the time step computation, only the radial mesh-size will be taken into account. To allow outflow of air, a transmitting boundary condition is added: FLOW 4 1 POSX +

  •                                                                   +       

  •       FLOW     OUT

As soon as material is starting to leave the 1-D mesh, the analysis has to be terminated. In this example cycle 3000 and time 1.1 ms will be taken for the remap. For details as how to import the 1-D results into the 3-D simulation refer to the previous example. For the remap text files have to be created for air density, JWL density, air specific internal energy (SIE), JWL SIE and radial velocity. These are called rhoa.xyd , rhoj.xyd , siea.xyd , siej.xyd , and velj.xyd . In the files containing density information the entries with zero densities have to be removed. Follow-up 3-D Model for the First Quadrant The Euler region is defined and initialized as follows: MESH,1,BOX,,,,,,,+ +,0,0,0,5,5,5,,,+ +,75,75,75,,,,EULER,1Ideal gas gamma 1.4 Specific internal energy =3.E+5 Joule/kg Density =1 kg/m3

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling the JWL Explosion using 1-D Spherical Symmetry118 Main Index Using the material fraction the position of the interface between JWL material and air in the 1-D run can be computed. This interface is at 2.83244 m. This is used in SPHERE to define a sphere of explosive products. TICEUL1 19 1 2 TICREG 1 1 SPHERE 3 100 8 2.0 TICREG 2 1 SPHERE 4 200 9 4.0 SPHERE,3,,0.0,0.0,0.0,10.0 SPHERE,4,,0.0,0.0,0.0,2.83244 TICVAL,8,RADIAL,X-CENTER,0,Y-CENTER,0,Z-CENTER,0,+ +,R-VEL,100,density,200,SIE,300 TICVAL,9,RADIAL,X-CENTER,0,Y-CENTER,0,Z-CENTER,0,+ +,R-VEL,100,density,400,SIE,500 $ $!-1—|—2—|—3—|—4—|—5—|—6—|—7—|—8—|—9- –|—0—|
$ TABFILE,100,velj.xyd TABLED1 100 +

entry is set to a sufficiently large value: DETSPH 1 200 .0 .0 .0 1E+12 0.0

This time represents the total problem time of 1.894 ms (1D + 3D). Radial Velocity at Cycle 1 Comparison with 1D Pressure at Time = 0.799 ms (Cycle 76)

This time represents the total problem time of 2.526 ms (1D + 3D). Abbreviated SOL 700 Input File Spherical Symmetric Model SOL 700,NLTRAN STOP=1 CEND ENDSTEP = 4000 $CHECK=NO $$TITLE= Jobname is: sphersym DLOAD=1 IC=1 SPC=1 $ $S700 TYPE (ALLEULER) = ARCHIVE $S700 ELEMENTS (ALLEULER) = 2 $S700 SET 2 = ALLMULTIEULHYDRO $S700 ELOUT (ALLEULER) = PRESSURE,XVEL,YVEL,ZVEL $S700 ELOUT (ALLEULER) = FMAT100,DENSITY100,SIE100 $S700 ELOUT (ALLEULER) = FMAT200,DENSITY200,SIE200,FBURN $S700 STEPS(ALLEULER) = 0,thru,end,by,300 $S700 SAVE (ALLEULER) = 10000 $——- Parameter Section —— PARAM,INISTEP,1.E-8 $ $——- BULK DATA SECTION ——- BEGIN BULK $ —————————————————————— $ DYPARAM,SPHERSYM,RECT,X,1.0 $ * Euler.300 * $ Pressure at Time =1.431ms (Cycle 100)

125 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling the JWL Explosion using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Main Index PARAM,MICRO,30 PEULER1,1,,MMHYDRO,19 $ ========= MATERIAL DEFINITIONS ========== EOSGAM,100,1.4 $ $DMAT 100 1.29 100 MATDEUL 100 1.29 100 $ $DMAT 200 1717. 200 MATDEUL 200 1717. 200 $ EOSJWL 200 5.242+117.6783+94.2 1.1 .34
$ DETSPH 1 200 .0 .0 .0 7980. 0.0
$ $ $TICEUL,19,,,,,,,,+ $+,SPHERE,3,100,8,4.0,,,,+ $+,SPHERE,4,200,9,6.0 SPHERE,3,,0.0,0.0,0,10000 SPHERE,4,,0.0,0.0,0.0,0.25 TICVAL,8,,density,1,sie,3e+5 TICVAL,9,,density,1717.,sie,4950000. $$ $ TICEUL1 19 1 2 TICREG 1 1 SPHERE 3 100 8 4.0 TICREG 2 1 SPHERE 4 200 9 6.0 $TICVAL 8 DENSITY 1 SIE 3E+5 $TICVAL 9 DENSITY 1717. ENDDATA 1-D – 3-D Spherical Symmetry and 2-D – 3-D Axial Symmetry Remap Blast wave simulations require fine elements near the explosion to capture the details of the pressure wave propagation and often require large 3-D Euler meshes that results in excessive CPU time. During most of this time, the blast wave expands without hitting any structure. It would be much more efficient do this expansion in free space with 2-D Axial Symmetric or 1-D Spherical Symmetric model to reduce the simulation time.
The results of the 2-D Axial symmetric or the 1-D Spherical Symmetric simulation are saved right before the blast wave hits the structure and then imported in the follow-up 3-D simulation. Here, the blast wave hits the structure in minimal CPU time. This capability results in significant performance improvements in blast wave simulations. Note: The 1-D-3-D spherical symmetry and 2-D-3D axial symmetry using remap technique is the new methodology to efficiently compute the blast loads as opposed to the previous two examples that used tables. In the previous examples, the initialization of a 3-D Euler mesh by 1-D spherical Euler results used the TABFILE entries that can be cumbersome.

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling the JWL Explosion using 1-D Spherical Symmetry128 Main Index The remap technique is a new and more user-friendly approach. The initialization is done by importing the 1-D spherical Euler archive directly into the 3-D Euler mesh. In addition, the initialization of a 3-D Euler mesh by a 2-D axial symmetric Euler results is illustrated.  The import of Euler archives is carried out by using the EULINIT entry. Refer to Chapter 2 of the Dytran Reference Manual for a description of the EULINIT entry. Features Two Stages Blast Wave Analysis Euler Archive Import from 1-D/2-D to 3-D meshes 2-D Axial Symmetry to 3-D Remap 1-D Spherical Symmetry to 3-D Remap Multiple usage Blast initialization Saving CPU time Using Suitable Units for Blast problem (m, kg, ms, MN, MPa, MJ) A. 2-D Axial Symmetric to 3-D Remap Model Description The 3-D model consists of rectangular box with dimensions of 12m x 6m x 6m with its origin at [0,0,0] and occupying the positive quadrant ( Figure 3-19). A cylindrical charge is assumed to be placed with its axis coinciding with the Z-axis. The box is meshed with a uniform Cartesian mesh, 120 x 60 x 60. The symmetry walls are rigid walls by default. The positive x, y, and z directions are defined as non-reflecting boundaries to prevent unwanted reflections. Figure 3-19 Model for 2-D Axial Symmetric to 3-D Remap Time history of the following four fixed gauge points will be created in the Euler domain: 1.[4.999,0.001,0.001] 2.[4.999,0.001,1.341] 3.[4.999,0.001,2.999] 4.[4.999,0.001,3.999] All four gauges are at a range of 5m from the origin, and so they are adjacent to the structure on the symmetry plane. They are intended for obtaining the reflected pressure from the rigid structure, as a function of the elevation from ground.

item.title: User's Manual P8
item.description:
129 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling the JWL Explosion using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Main Index The axially symmetric run was calculated in the XZ-plane, for a 5m x 6m domain. This domain was meshed by 200 x 240 elements, so that the charge radius included 14 elements. The 250kg charge is represented by an “energetic” air, to allow a single material calculation. The charge is a cylinder with L/D=2, elevated 1m above ground. For Axial Symmetric Analysis, the following parameter is used: DYPARAM, AXIALSYM, AXIAL, Z, ZX, 2.5 A total of three runs will be carried out: a.A full run with first order accuracy (option HYDRO ). b.An axially symmetric 2-D run with a fine mesh. c.A remap run with first order accuracy at time = 0.5 ms . Figure 3-20 Axial Symmetric Model (a) Full Run (b) Axial Symmetry (c) Remap

Pressure Time History Results From Markers Remarks 1.Higher peak pressures, as obtained in (c), are the result of four times finer meshing in the axial-symmetric model (b) . 2.Unit system: m, kg, ms, MN, MPa, MJ, gravity = 9.8 E-6 m/(ms)2 .Time = 4.5 ms Time = 4.5 ms Time = 4.5 ms(a) Normal 3-D Run (b) Axial symmetry 2-D Run (c) 3-D Remap Run Normal 3-D Run 2-D-3-D Remap Run

Demonstration Guide (SOL 700) Explicit Nonlinear Modeling the JWL Explosion using 1-D Spherical Symmetry136 Main Index B. 1-D Spherical Symmetric to 3-D Remap Model Description Blast wave simulations with structures pose a meshing problem when the distance between the structure and the charge is relatively large. As an example, consider a spherical charge of 1kg TNT explosive, with a charge radius of about 50mm, and a structure placed at a distance of 1 meter. It is reasonable to mesh the space between the charge and the structure with 20mm cells, but such meshing is not suitable for representing the explosive charge. (Especially if it is desired to use the JWL burn logic which requires many cells along the charge radius in order to obtain reliable modeling of the detonation). A possible workaround is the use of a biased mesh, starting with small elements near the charge and larger elements near the structure. This can help to a certain degree, but it has the disadvantage of the time step being controlled by the small elements during the entire simulation. SOL 700 has a specific feature to handle such a situation. The simulation is carried out in two stages. First, a spherical (1-D) calculation is carried out with a fine mesh to a desired time that would bring the blast wave in close proximity of the structure. Second, the spherical solution is mapped into the 3-D mesh which includes the structure. The remapping of the fine mesh solution into the 3-D relatively coarse mesh is accomplished with mass, energy and momentum conservation. The model consists of a cube with dimensions of 1m x 1m x 1m, with its origin at [0,0,0] and occupying the positive quadrant ( Figure 3-21). A spherical charge is assumed to be placed with its center coinciding with the origin. Thus only one eighth of the charge will be included in the cube. The cube is meshed with a uniform Cartesian mesh, 80 x 80 x 80. The boundary walls are assumed rigid (by default). Time history of four gauge points will be created: 1.[0.999,0.001,0.001] 2.[0.707,0.001,0.707] 3.[0.577,0.577,0.577] 4.[0.001,0.001,0.001] The first three points are at a range of 1m from the origin. The first point serves to get the reflected pressure from a rigid wall, the second and third are for incident pressure. Figure 3-21 Model for Spherical Symmetry Remap

137 Chapter 3: Fluid Dynamics Modeling the JWL Explosion using 1-D Spherical Symmetry Main Index A total of three runs will be carried out: a.A full run with first order accuracy (option HYDRO ). b.A spherically symmetric 1-D run with a fine mesh. c.A remap run at time = 0.3 ms . Figure 3-22 Spherical Symmetry Model A.
